====Federal budget==== Manchin has co-sponsored [[balanced budget amendment]]s put forth by Senators [[Mike Lee (U.S. politician)|Mike Lee]] (R-UT),<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wvgazette.com/News/201103021152?page=2 |title=Manchin questions U.S. role in Afghanistan |last=Nyden |first=Paul J. |date=March 2, 2011 |newspaper=[[Charleston Gazette]] |access-date=October 12, 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120716013501/http://wvgazette.com/News/201103021152?page=2 |archive-date=July 16, 2012}}</ref> [[Richard Shelby]] (R-AL), and [[Mark Udall]] (D-CO).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wvgazette.com/News/201104261087?page=2 |title=Manchin launches 'Commonsense' tour |last=Nyden |first=Paul J. |date=April 26, 2011 |newspaper=Charleston Gazette |access-date=October 12, 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028170602/http://wvgazette.com/News/201104261087?page=2 |archive-date=October 28, 2013}}</ref> He has also voted against raising the federal debt ceiling.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wvgazette.com/News/201201270144 |title=Rockefeller, Manchin cast opposite votes on debt ceiling |date=January 27, 2012 |newspaper=Charleston Gazette |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref>
Manchin has expressed strong opposition to entitlement reform, describing Mitch McConnell's comments in October 2018 on the need to reform entitlement programs such as Social Security, Medicaid and Medicare as "absolutely ridiculous."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/10/21/entitlements-mcconnell-manchin-midterms-920027|title='Campaign gold': McConnell delivers election gift to Manchin and red-state Dems|work=POLITICO|access-date=2018-10-21|language=en}}</ref>
====Guns==== In 2012 Manchin's candidacy was endorsed by the [[National Rifle Association]] (NRA), which gave him an "A" rating.<ref>{{cite web |title=NRA-PVF Endorses Joe Manchin for U.S. Senate in West Virginia |url=http://www.nrapvf.org/news-alerts/2012/10/nra-pvf-endorses-joe-manchin-for-us-senate-in-west-virginia.aspx |website=NRA Political Victory Fund |date=October 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213173935/http://www.nrapvf.org/news-alerts/2012/10/nra-pvf-endorses-joe-manchin-for-us-senate-in-west-virginia.aspx |archivedate=December 13, 2013 |df=}}</ref> Following the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting|Sandy Hook shooting]], Manchin partnered with Republican senator [[Pat Toomey]] to introduce a bill that would have strengthened background checks on gun sales. The Manchin-Toomey bill was defeated on April 17, 2013, by a vote of 54–46; 60 votes would have been required to pass it.<ref name="usatoday.com"/> Despite the fact that the bill did not pass, the NRA targeted Manchin in an attack ad.<ref>{{cite news |last=Friedman |first=Dan |title=Sen. Joe Manchin drawing straws for votes on gun background check |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/sen-joe-manchin-draws-support-background-checks-article-1.1373527 |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Terkel |first=Amanda |title=Joe Manchin Targeted By NRA In New Ad |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/12/joe-manchin-nra-ad_n_3430529.html |website=[[Huffington Post]] |accessdate=June 17, 2013 |date=June 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Bresnahan |first=John |title=Joe Manchin takes on NRA in TV spot |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/joe-manchin-nra-tv-spot-gun-92879.html |date=June 17, 2013 |website=Politico |accessdate=June 17, 2013}}</ref>
Manchin was criticized in 2013 for agreeing to an interview with ''[[The Journal (West Virginia newspaper)|The Journal]]'' in [[Martinsburg, West Virginia]], but demanding that he not be asked any questions about gun control or the Second Amendment.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Simpson |first1=Connor |title=Sen. Joe Manchin Really Doesn't Want to Talk About Guns |url=http://www.thewire.com/politics/2013/03/sen-joe-manchin-really-doesnt-want-talk-about-guns/62701/ |accessdate=August 14, 2014 |website=The Wire |date=March 3, 2013}}</ref>
In 2016, referring to the difficulty of keeping guns out of the hands of potential terrorists, Manchin said, "due process is what's killing us right now." This comment drew the criticism of both the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] and the [[Cato Institute]], which accused Manchin of attacking a fundamental constitutional principle. "With all respect," commented Ilya Shapiro of Cato, "due process is the essential basis of America."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shapiro |first1=Ilya |title=Does Joe Manchin Want to Make America a Police State? |url=https://www.cato.org/blog/does-joe-manchin-want-make-america-police-state |date=June 16, 2016 |website=Cato Institute |accessdate=March 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sen. Joe Manchin Reveals Gross Contempt for U.S. Constitution |url=https://www.nraila.org/articles/20160616/sen-joe-manchin-reveals-gross-contempt-for-us-constitution |date=June 16, 2016 |website=[[NRA-ILA]] |accessdate=March 26, 2018}}</ref>
====Health care==== In 2010, Manchin called for "repairs" of the Affordable Care Act and repeal of the "bad parts of Obamacare".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/joe-manchin-obamacare-fixes-233541 |title=Manchin: I'll help GOP 'repair' Obamacare |first=Elana |last=Schor |date=January 12, 2017 |website=Politico |access-date=September 21, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/17/upshot/democrats-campaign-ads-pre-existing-conditions.html |title=No. 1 Aim of Democratic Campaign Ads: Protect Pre-existing Conditions |first=Margot |last=Sanger-Katz |date=September 17, 2018 |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=September 21, 2018}}</ref> On January 14, 2017, Manchin expressed concern at the strict party-line vote on repealing Obamacare and said he could not, in good conscience, vote to repeal without a new plan in place. He added, however, that he was willing to work with Trump and the GOP to formulate a replacement.<ref>{{cite web |last1=O'Brien |first1=Soledad |title=Sen. Joe Manchin On The Affordable Care Act |url=http://matteroffact.tv/sen-joe-manchin-affordable-care-act/ |date=January 14, 2017 |website=Matter of Fact.tv |accessdate=March 27, 2018}}</ref> In June 2017, Manchin and [[Bob Casey Jr.]] of Pennsylvania warned that repealing Obamacare would worsen the [[Opioid epidemic|opioid crisis]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Potter |first1=Chris |title=Bob Casey and Joe Manchin: Senate plan to repeal Obamacare would worsen opioid epidemic |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/news/overdosed/2017/06/20/Opioid-crisis-epidemic-overdose-Bob-Casey-Joe-Manchin-Obamacare-Senate-repeal/stories/201706200111 |date=June 20, 2017 |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |accessdate=March 27, 2018}}</ref> In July 2017, he said that he was one of about ten senators from both parties who had been "working together behind the scenes" to formulate a new health-care program, but that there was otherwise insufficient bipartisanship on the issue.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Beavers |first1=Olivia |title=Manchin clarifies that he is 'skeptical' of single-payer system |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/350313-manchin-clarifies-that-he-is-skeptical-of-single-payer-system |date=September 12, 2017 |newspaper=The Hill |accessdate=March 26, 2018}}</ref>
During 2016-17, Manchin read to the Senate several letters from constituents about loved ones' deaths from opioids and urged his colleagues to act to prevent more deaths. Manchin took "an unusual proposal" to President Trump to address the crisis and called for a "war on drugs" that involves not punishment but treatment. He proposed the LifeBOAT Act, which would fund treatment. He also opposes [[Legalization of marijuana|marijuana legalization]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Blau |first1=Max |title=Senator Joe Manchin: Time for a new 'war on drugs' to tackle opioids |url=https://www.statnews.com/2017/03/27/manchin-opioid-war-on-drugs/ |date=March 27, 2017 |website=[[Stat (website)|STAT]] |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=King |first1=Joselyn |title=Sen. Joe Manchin Visits Unity Center in Benwood |url=http://www.theintelligencer.net/news/top-headlines/2018/02/sen-joe-manchin-visits-unity-center-in-benwood/ |date=February 3, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Intelligencer and Wheeling News Register]] |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref> In January 2018, Manchin was one of six Democrats who broke with their party to vote to confirm Trump's nominee for Health Secretary, [[Alex Azar]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/370511-senate-advances-trumps-health-secretary-nominee |title=Senate confirms Trump health secretary |last=Cohn |first=Alicia |date=January 24, 2018 |newspaper=The Hill |access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref>
In his 2018 re-election campaign, Manchin emphasized his support for Obamacare, running an ad where he shot holes in a lawsuit that sought to repeal the Affordable Care Act.<ref name=":3" />
====Immigration==== Manchin is opposed to the [[DREAM Act]], and was absent from a 2010 vote on the bill.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/12/joe-manchin-absent-for-dream-a.html |title=Joe Manchin absent for two major Senate votes |newspaper=The Washington Post |last=Sonmez |first=Felicia |date=December 18, 2010 |access-date=September 28, 2018}}</ref> Manchin supports the construction of a [[Border barrier|wall]] along the southern border of the United States.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2010/12/dream-act-dies-in-senate-046573 |title=DREAM Act dies in Senate |first1=Scott |last1=Wong |first2=Shira |last2=Toeplitz |date=December 18, 2010 |website=Politico |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/392350-manchin-touts-support-for-trump-border-wall-in-new-ad |title=Manchin touts support for Trump border wall in new ad |last=Wise |first=Justin |date=June 14, 2018 |newspaper=The Hill |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref> Manchin voted against the McCain-Coons proposal to create a pathway to citizenship for some undocumented immigrants without funding for a border wall and he voted against a comprehensive immigration bill proposed by [[Susan Collins]] which gave a pathway to citizenship for [[DREAM Act|Dreamers]] as well as funding for border security; he voted 'yes' to withholding funding for '[[Sanctuary city|sanctuary cities]]' and he voted in support of President Trump's proposal to give a pathway to citizenship for Dreamers, build a border wall, and reduce legal immigration.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/16/heres-how-your-senators-voted-on-failed-immigration-proposals.html |title=Here's how your senators voted on failed immigration proposals |last=Schoen |first=John W. |date=February 16, 2018 |website=CNBC |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.politifact.com/west-virginia/statements/2018/oct/05/joe-manchin/did-joe-manchin-vote-fund-border-wall/ |title=Did Joe Manchin vote to fund the border wall? |date=October 5, 2018 |website=Politifact |access-date=October 8, 2018}}</ref>
Manchin has mixed ratings from political action committees opposed to illegal immigration; [[NumbersUSA]], which seeks to reduce illegal and legal immigration, gave Manchin a 55% rating and the [[Federation for American Immigration Reform]], which also seeks to reduce legal immigration, gave him a 25% rating.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/7547/joe-manchin-iii/40 |title=Joe Manchin III's Ratings and Endorsements on Issue: Immigration |website=Vote Smart |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref>
====LGBT rights==== On December 9, 2010, Manchin was the sole Democrat to vote against [[cloture]] for the 2011 [[National Defense Authorization Act]], which contained a provision to repeal [[Don't ask, don't tell|Don't Ask, Don't Tell]]. In an interview with ''[[The Associated Press]]'', Manchin cited the advice of retired military chaplains as a basis for his decision to vote against repeal.<ref name="Chaplains">{{cite web |title=Manchin: Chaplains May Leave Military If 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' is Repealed |date=December 3, 2010 |website=WOWK-TV |url=http://www.wowktv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=90524 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101211105707/http://wowktv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=90524 |archivedate=December 11, 2010 |df=}}</ref> He also indicated he wanted more time to "hear the full range of viewpoints from the citizens of West Virginia."<ref name="Knezevich DADT">{{cite news |last=Knezevich |first=Alison |title=Manchin lone Democrat to oppose 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' repeal |url=http://www.wvgazette.com/News/201012091323 |accessdate=December 10, 2010 |newspaper=[[Charleston Gazette]] |date=December 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212235141/http://www.wvgazette.com/News/201012091323 |archivedate=December 12, 2010 |df=}}</ref> A day later, he was publicly criticized at a gay rights rally for his position on the bill.<ref>{{cite web |title=Joe Manchin booed over 'Don't ask' vote |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1210/46244.html |website=Politico |first=Scott |last=Wong |date=December 10, 2010 |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref>
{{as of|2013}}, he was one of three Democratic senators who still opposed same-sex marriage, and {{as of|2015|lc=y}}, he was the only Democratic senator who opposed gay marriage.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2015/03/02/manchin-wont-back-dem-effort-support-marriage/ |title=Manchin won't back Dems effort in support of marriage equality |date=March 2, 2015 |newspaper=[[Washington Blade]] |access-date=July 12, 2018}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' attributed his opposition to "ideology, rather than electoral concerns," noting his votes against the repeal of "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" and for the [[Defense of Marriage Act]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Enten |first1=Harry J. |title=The final three: the Democratic senators against gay marriage |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/apr/10/last-democrats-against-gay-marriage |date=April 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=March 26, 2018}}</ref> The [[Human Rights Campaign]], a PAC which supports same-sex marriage and other [[LGBT]] rights, gave Manchin an 85% scoring in line with their positions in 2016, a 0% in 2014, and a 65% in 2012.<ref name=":2" />
====Senior citizens==== To help locate missing senior citizens, Manchin introduced the [[Silver Alert]] Act in July 2011 to create a nationwide network for locating missing adults and senior citizens modeled after the [[AMBER Alert]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wvmetronews.com/news.cfm?func=displayfullstory&storyid=44122 |title=West Virginia Metro News |website=West Virginia Metro News |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> Manchin also sponsored the National Yellow Dot Act to create a voluntary program that would alert emergency services personnel responding to car accidents of the availability of personal and medical information on the car's owner.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsandsentinel.com/page/content.detail/id/557859/Bill-unveiled-for-seniors-in-emergency-situations.html?nav=5061 |title=Bill unveiled for seniors in emergency situations |newspaper=The Parkersburg News and Sentinel |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref>
Manchin said in 2014 that he "would change Social Security completely. I would do it on an inflationary basis, as far as paying into payroll taxes, and change that, to keep us stabilized as far as cash flow. I'd do COLAs—I'd talk about [[Cost of living|COLA]] for 250 percent of poverty guidelines." Asked whether this meant he would "cut benefits to old people," Manchin said that "a rich old person...won't get the COLAs." He asked: "Do you want [[United States Chained Consumer Price Index|chained CPI]]? I can live with either one."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Weigel |first1=David |title=Joe Manchin, Grover Norquist, and the Economic Consensus of #ThisTown |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/weigel/2014/03/18/joe_manchin_grover_norquist_and_the_economic_consensus_of_thistown.html |date=March 18, 2014 |website=Slate |accessdate=March 26, 2018}}</ref>
====Supreme Court nominations==== Manchin was the first Democrat to say he would vote for Trump's first nominee for the Supreme Court, [[Neil Gorsuch]]. Manchin said, "During his time on the bench, Judge Gorsuch has received praise from his colleagues who have been appointed by both Democrats and Republicans. He has been consistently rated as a well-qualified jurist, the highest rating a jurist can receive, and I have found him to be an honest and thoughtful man."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://wvrecord.com/stories/511099958-law-courts-manchin-becomes-first-democrat-to-say-he-ll-vote-for-gorsuch |title=Manchin becomes first Democrat to say he'll vote for Gorsuch |last=Dickerson |first=Chris |date=March 30, 2017 |newspaper=West Virginia Record |access-date=December 1, 2017}}</ref>
He was the first Democrat to announce that he would meet with Trump's second Supreme Court nominee, [[Brett Kavanaugh]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/07/25/supreme-court-pick-shakes-up-west-virginia-senate-race.html |title=Supreme Court pick shakes up West Virginia Senate race |last=Doocy |first=Peter |date=July 25, 2018 |website=Fox News |access-date=July 25, 2018}}</ref> Manchin was the only Democrat to vote 'yes' on the cloture of Kavanaugh's nomination, advancing the motion to a final vote.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/05/manchin-murkowski-vote-buck-party-lines-in-key-vote-on-kavanaugh.html |title=Facing pressure at home, Manchin and Murkowski buck party lines in key vote on Kavanaugh |last=Higgins |first=Tucker |date=October 5, 2018 |website=CNBC |access-date=October 5, 2018}}</ref> On October 5, 2018, he announced he would vote to confirm Kavanaugh.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Fandos |first1=Nicholas |last2=Stolberg |first2=Sheryl |title=Collins and Manchin Will Vote for Kavanaugh, All but Ensuring His Confirmation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/05/us/politics/brett-kavanaugh-vote-confirmed.html |accessdate=October 5, 2018 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 5, 2018}}</ref> On October 6, Manchin was the only Democrat to vote to confirm Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court in a 50-48 count.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/10/06/us/politics/kavanaugh-live-vote-senate-confirmation.html |title=How Every Senator Voted on Kavanaugh's Confirmation |last=Daniel |first=Annie |date=October 6, 2018 |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=October 6, 2018}}</ref>
====Taxes==== According to ''[[Politico]]'', Manchin sees Trump's [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] as "a closed process" that "makes little impact in the paychecks of the people in his state." At the same time, he posited the bill contains "some good things...Initially people will benefit", although ultimately voting against it. In turn, NRSC spokesman Bob Salera stated that he had "turned his back and voted with Washington Democrats."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dovere |first1=Edward-Isaac |title='I Was An Easy Pickup': How Trump Lost Manchin on Taxes |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/12/19/joe-manchin-interview-trump-franken-podcast-216118 |date=December 19, 2017 |website=Politico |accessdate=March 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Drucker |first1=David M. |title=Joe Manchin struggles to explain opposition to GOP tax bill |url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/joe-manchin-struggles-to-explain-opposition-to-gop-tax-bill |date=December 20, 2017 |website=[[The Washington Examiner]] |accessdate=March 24, 2018}}</ref>
====Terrorism==== In June 2017, he was one of five Democrats who, by voting against a Senate resolution disapproving of arms sales to [[Saudi Arabia]], ensured its failure. Potential primary opponent [[Paula Jean Swearengin]] charged that because of Manchin's vote, weapons sold to the Saudis "could possibly end up in the hands of terrorists."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jilani |first1=Zaid |title=Joe Manchin was one of five Democrats who saved Saudi arms sales. His primary opponent is furious. |url=https://theintercept.com/2017/06/19/joe-manchin-saudi-arabia-arms-primary-swearengin/ |date=June 19, 2017 |website=The Intercept |accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref>
===Committee assignments=== *[[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Committee on Appropriations]] **[[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies]] **[[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government|Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government]] **[[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security|Subcommittee on Homeland Security]] **[[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies]] **[[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies]] *[[United States Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources|Committee on Energy and Natural Resources]] **[[United States Senate Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on Energy|Subcommittee on Energy]] **[[United States Senate Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on Public Lands, Forests, and Mining|Subcommittee on Public Lands, Forests, and Mining]] **[[United States Senate Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee on Water and Power|Subcommittee on Water and Power]] *[[Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] *[[Senate Veterans' Affairs Committee]]
==Personal life== Manchin is a member of the [[National Rifle Association]] and a licensed pilot.<ref name="USNews" /><ref>{{cite web |title=Governor Manchin Speaks Out on Pro-Life |url=http://www.wvnstv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=6580 |date=November 11, 2005 |accessdate=May 11, 2009 |website=WVNS-TV |publisher=West Virginia Media Holdings, LLC |last=Jones |first=Katherine |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826025257/http://www.wvnstv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=6580 |archivedate=August 26, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=W.Va. Gov. In No Rush To End Race |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/05/09/politics/politicalplayers/main4082837.shtml |date=May 9, 2008 |accessdate=December 30, 2010 |website=CBSNews.com |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |last=Goldsmith |first=Brian}}</ref> In 1967, he married [[Gayle Conelly Manchin|Gayle Conelly]]. Together they have three children: [[Heather Bresch|Heather]], Joseph IV, and Brooke.<ref name="USNews" />
In 2006 and 2010 Manchin delivered commencement addresses at [[Wheeling Jesuit University]] and at [[Davis & Elkins College]], receiving honorary degrees from both institutions.
In December 2012, Manchin voiced his displeasure with [[MTV]]'s new reality show ''[[Buckwild (TV series)|Buckwild]]'', set in his home state's capital Charleston, and asked the network's president to cancel the show, which, he argued, depicted West Virginia in a negative, unrealistic fashion.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/wp/2012/12/07/joe-manchin-objects-to-mtvs-buckwild-reality-show/ |title=Joe Manchin objects to MTV's 'Buckwild' reality show |last=O'Keefe |first=Ed |date=December 7, 2012 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=}}</ref> The show ended after its first season.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Buckwild |date=January 3, 2013 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2555880/ |website=[[IMDb]] |accessdate=January 29, 2017}}</ref>
==Controversies== ===Heather Bresch=== [[West Virginia University]] (WVU) awarded Manchin's daughter, [[Heather Bresch]], an [[MBA]] in 2007, the year she became [[Chief Operations Officer|COO]] at [[Mylan Inc.]], the third largest generic pharmaceutical manufacturer in the U.S. with headquarters in Morgantown, adjacent to the WVU campus. The ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' reported that in order to justify this degree, university officials had added courses to her transcript that she had never taken and altered grades she had received. The ensuing controversy resulted in the rescinding of her MBA and the resignation of the university president, Mike Garrison, a Manchin family friend, and Garrison's legal counsel and the Dean of the Business School. A panel was convened to fully investigate the measure.<ref name="huntingtonnews.net">{{cite news |title=Joe Manchin III: The Harry Houdini of West Virginia Politics |url=http://www.huntingtonnews.net/8650 |newspaper=The Huntington News |accessdate=April 26, 2012 |date=September 1, 2011}}</ref> When the MBA controversy erupted, according to ''[[The Huntington News]]'', Manchin "act[ed] as though he and his wife, Gayle, were somehow the victims of this hoax that almost cost WVU its academic credibility." According to the Huntington News, "the Manchins were seen as people willing to destroy [the university's] reputation rather than admit a mistake."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/opinion/editorials/message-for-wvu-the-board-of-governors-must-restore-credibility-394283 |title=Message for WVU: The board of governors must restore credibility |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date=May 16, 2008 |accessdate=April 26, 2012}}</ref>
Noting in a December 2011 editorial that the magazine ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' had promoted Heather Bresch as an "American hero" owing to her support for a pharma safety law, the ''Huntington News'' pointed out that the law also protected U.S. pharma firms like Mylan and suggested that the article was a "public makeover" engineered by "the Manchin public relations machine." It also said that Mylan "must have the only corporate Board of Directors in the country that doesn't care about one of their top execs being proven to have a phony MBA degree."<ref>{{cite news |title=Editorial: The Manchin PR Machine Keeps Rollin'. But Who Buys It? |url=http://www.huntingtonnews.net/8650 |newspaper=The Huntington News |accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref>
Despite Manchin's call for a war on drugs, particularly opioids, and his charge that "Big Pharma" had "targeted" his state, Manchin's daughter, as noted, is the CEO of Mylan, a pharmaceutical firm that produces opioids, and Manchin himself accepted "nearly $180,000 in donations from pharmaceutical companies between 2011 and 2016."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Siegel |first1=Zachary |title=West Virginia Senator Joe Manchin: We Need To Declare A War on Drugs |url=https://www.thefix.com/west-virginia-senator-joe-manchin-we-need-declare-war-drugs |date=December 22, 2016 |website=The Fix |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref> In August 2016, ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' and the ''[[Washington Post]]'' ran a total of three articles about the fact that the "CEO of the company at the center of the [[EpiPen]] controversy" was Manchin's daughter. The articles noted that skyrocketing EpiPen costs were "the next big flash point in the national debate over skyrocketing prescription drug prices," that Bresch had originally gotten her Mylan job through her father, and that her career had "risen along with her father's, a fact that has not gone unnoticed by her critics." A particular point of controversy was the fact that Bresch had transferred Mylan's official headquarters to the Netherlands, a tax dodge maneuver known as [[tax inversion]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wieczner |first1=Jen |title=The Truth About Mylan CEO's 'Heather Bresch Situation' and Her MBA |url=http://fortune.com/2016/08/26/epipen-mylan-ceo-interview-heather-bresch-mba/ |date=August 26, 2016 |website=Fortune |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref>
===Family lawsuit=== In a lawsuit filed in July 2014, Dr. John Manchin II, one of Joe Manchin's brothers, sued Joe Manchin and his other brother, Roch Manchin, over a $1.7 million loan. The lawsuit alleged that Joe and Roch Manchin borrowed the money to keep the doors open at the family-owned carpet business run by Roch, that no part of the loan had yet been repaid, and that the defendants had taken other measures to evade compensating John Manchin II for non-payment.<ref name="ManchinBadLoan">{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jul/25/us-sen-joe-manchin-sued-by-brother-over-loan/ |title=Joe Manchin sued by brother over loan |date=July 25, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Times |accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> Dr. Manchin withdrew the suit on June 30, 2015.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gallagher |first1=Emily |newspaper=[[Times West Virginian]] |title=John Manchin drops lawsuit against two brothers |date=June 30, 2015 |url=http://wvpress.org/news/john-manchin-drops-lawsuit-against-two-brothers/ |accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Manchin's coal interests=== In July 2011, ''[[The New York Times]]'' ran a long article headlined "Sen. Manchin Maintains Lucrative Ties to Family-Owned Coal Company." Manchin's 2009 and 2010 financial disclosures included major earnings from Enersystems Inc., "a coal brokerage that he helped run before his political star rose." Many senators earn business income, but Manchin is rare in that "he derives income from an industry while acting as one of its biggest boosters."<ref name="lucrative-ties"/>
===Skipping votes and convention=== On December 18, 2010, Manchin skipped the vote to repeal Don't Ask, Don't Tell and the vote on the [[DREAM Act]], regarding immigration. The [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] criticized Manchin for attending a family Christmas gathering instead of voting on these important issues. "For a Senator who has only been on the job a few weeks," commented the NRSC, "Manchin's absence today, and the apparent lack of seriousness with which he takes the job he was elected to do, speaks volumes."<ref name="Skip votes">{{cite web |title=Joe Manchin Skipped DREAM And DADT Votes For A Christmas Party |first=Jillian |last=Rayfield |date=December 18, 2010 |website=[[Talking Points Memo]] |url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/12/joe-manchin-skipped-dream-and-dadt-votes-for-a-christmas-party.php}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that he was the only Senate Democrat to miss these votes "on two of his party's signature pieces of legislation."<ref>{{cite news |title=Joe Manchin absent for two major Senate votes |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/12/joe-manchin-absent-for-dream-a.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=May 4, 2012 |first=Felicia |last=Sonmez |date=December 18, 2010}}</ref> Later, in 2012, Manchin also skipped the Democratic National Convention, saying he planned "to spend this fall focused on the people of West Virginia."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hamby |first1=Peter |last2=Killough |first2=Ashley |title=Manchin to skip Democratic National Convention |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/06/18/manchin-to-skip-democratic-national-convention/ |date=June 18, 2012 |website=Political Ticker - CNN |accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref>

{{More footnotes|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox person | name = Jordan Roth | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{bda|1975|11|13}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = Majority owner of [[Jujamcyn Amusement Corporation|Jujamcyn Theaters]] | education = | alma mater = [[Princeton University]]
[[Columbia Business School]] | employer = | occupation = Business owner | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = Richie Jackson (m. 2012) | children = | parents = [[Steven Roth]]
[[Daryl Roth]] | relatives = }} '''Jordan Roth''' (born November 13, 1975) is the President and majority owner{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2013/legit/news/roth-ups-his-stake-in-jujamcyn-1118064913 |title= Roth ups his stake in Jujamcyn |last=Cohen |first=Patricia |work=Variety |date= September 8, 2009}} of [[Jujamcyn Amusement Corporation|Jujamcyn Theaters]], where he oversees five Broadway theatres, including the [[St. James Theatre|St. James]], [[Al Hirschfeld Theatre|Al Hirschfeld]], [[August Wilson Theatre|August Wilson]], [[Eugene O'Neill Theatre|Eugene O'Neill]] and [[Walter Kerr Theatre|Walter Kerr]]. Jujamcyn Theaters has a history of presenting award-winning musicals and plays including ''[[The Book of Mormon (musical)|The Book of Mormon]]'', ''[[Springsteen on Broadway|Springsteen On Broadway]]'', and ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.jujamcyn.com/ |title=Official Jujamcyn Website |author= |accessdate= September 3, 2014}} Roth produced the Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award-winning Best Play ''Clybourne Park''.{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2012/02/jordan-roth-clybourne-parks-broadway-producer-makes-west-coast-swing.html |title=Jordan Roth, 'Clybourne Park's' Broadway producer, makes West Coast swing |last=Boehm |first=Mike |work=LA Times |date=February 11, 2012}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0BV2NBQzQ5A |title=Acceptance Speech: Best Play, Clybourne Park (2012) |author= |date= June 10, 2012 |website= YouTube}} ==Early life== Roth is the son of [[Steven Roth]], a billionaire real estate developer, and [[Daryl Roth]], a New York theater producer.{{cite web |url=http://forward.com/articles/152696/romney-pac-attracts-new-jewish-donors/?p=all |title=Romney PAC Attracts New Jewish Donors |last=Nathan-Kazis |first=Josh |work=The Jewish Daily Forward |date=March 16, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/jordan-roth-is-now-principal-owner-of-broadways-jujamcyn-theaters |title=Jordan Roth Is Now Principal Owner of Broadway's Jujamcyn Theaters |last=Jones |first=Kenneth |work=Playbill |date=January 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904200700/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/jordan-roth-is-now-principal-owner-of-broadways-jujamcyn-theaters |archivedate=September 4, 2014 |df= }} Roth graduated ''summa cum laude'' and [[Phi Beta Kappa]] from [[Princeton University]] with degrees in philosophy and theatre, and received his MBA from [[Columbia Business School]].{{cite news|last1=Kao|first1=Joanna S.|title=How a Columbia MBA took impresario Jordan Roth to the next stage|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c4a875e2-d9af-11e6-944b-e7eb37a6aa8e|accessdate=March 1, 2018|work=Financial Times|date=January 23, 2017}} ==Career== Roth explored interactive theatrical experiences in the 1999 production of ''The Donkey Show'', a disco club event combining elements of both theater and nightlife.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/09/theater/09theater.html?_r=2& |title=A New Force on Broadway |last=Cohen |first=Patricia |work=The New York Times|date=Sep 8, 2009}} Performed in a New York nightclub, ''The Donkey Show'' invited audiences to watch the show around them on the dance floor, and then stay after the show to celebrate at the venue. Retelling the story of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' entirely through disco hits, ''The Donkey Show'' was described by ''[[The New York Times]]'' as "an indication of things to come in the theatre." The show ran for six years in New York, and has toured internationally. Roth followed ''The Donkey Show'' with a Broadway production of ''[[The Rocky Horror Show]]''. Through the course of the run, the cast included [[Dick Cavett]], [[Joan Jett]], [[Luke Perry]], [[Sebastian Bach]], [[Ana Gasteyer]], and a rotation of guest narrators including [[Jerry Springer]], [[Penn & Teller]], [[Robin Leach]], [[Sally Jessy Raphael]], [[Gilbert Gottfried]], [[Cindy Adams]], and [[Dave Holmes (actor)|Dave Holmes]]. Cited by ''Newsday'' as "the young blood Broadway so desperately craves," the show was nominated for a [[Tony award|Tony Award]] for Best Musical Revival in 2001. ''The Rocky Horror Show'' was nominated for four Tony Awards, five [[Drama Desk Award]]s, two [[Outer Critics Circle Award]]s, and a [[Drama League Award]]. Roth is also the Founder and CEO of social network website Culturalist.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2014/legit/people-news/jordan-roth-makes-legit-moves-in-digital-space-120104 |title=Jordan Roth Makes Legit Moves in Digital Space |last=Cox |first=Gordon |work=Variety|date=January 10, 2014}} He also hosts a popular interview series "Broadway Talks" at the 92nd Street Y, facilitating one-on-one discussions with prominent Broadway actors.{{cite web |url=http://www.92y.org/BroadwayTalks |title=Broadway Talks with Jordan Roth |author= |accessdate= September 10, 2014 |website= 92Y.org}} Recent guests have included Bono and the Edge, Daniel Radcliffe, Harry Connick, Jr., Nathan Lane, Laura Linney, Elaine Stritch and Harvey Fierstein. Roth created Givenik.com, a service allowing theatergoers to buy discounted tickets and give 5% of their ticket price to the charity of their choice.{{cite web |url=http://givenik.com/ |title=Givenik.com |author= |accessdate= September 10, 2014 |website= Givenik.com}} Givenik.com currently supports over 500 charitable organizations from major national agencies to local PTA groups. On television, Roth has appeared on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" as their Broadway correspondent, and has played himself in a recurring role on the NBC television series "Smash."{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/jordan-roth-is-now-principal-owner-of-broadways-jujamcyn-theaters |title=Jordan Roth Is Now Principal Owner of Broadway's Jujamcyn Theaters |last=Jones |first=Kenneth |work=Playbill |date=January 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904200700/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/jordan-roth-is-now-principal-owner-of-broadways-jujamcyn-theaters |archivedate=September 4, 2014 |df= }} ==Personal== Roth married Richie Jackson, executive producer of the [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]] series ''[[Nurse Jackie]]'', in September 2012.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/16/fashion/weddings/richie-jackson-and-jordan-roth-vows.html?pagewanted=all |title=Weddings/Celebrations: Richie Jackson and Jordan Roth |last=Schwartz |first=Paula |work=The New York Times|date=September 14, 2012}} With Jackson, ex-partner of actor [[B. D. Wong]], Roth co-parents their son .[http://www.playbill.com/article/to-love-someone-and-to-be-a-father-gay-parenting-in-the-modern-age Jackson Foo Wong] Roth serves on the Board of Trustees of [[Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS]],{{cite web|title=Board of Trustees|url=https://broadwaycares.org/board-of-trustees/|website=Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS|accessdate=March 1, 2018}} [[Freedom to Marry]],{{cite web|title=The Team|url=http://www.freedomtomarry.org/the-team|website=Freedom To Marry|accessdate=March 1, 2018}} and [[The Broadway League]].{{cite web|title=Board of Governors|url=https://www.broadwayleague.com/about/governors/|website=The Broadway League|accessdate=March 1, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roth, Jordan}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:American Jews]] [[Category:Horace Mann School alumni]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:LGBT people from the United States]] [[Category:LGBT producers]] [[Category:Columbia Business School alumni]] [[Category:Roth family]]

revision.text:
[[File:Jorge Antonio 1965.jpg|thumb|Jorge Antonio]] '''Jorge Antonio''' (October 14, 1917{{spaced ndash}}February 11, 2007) was an [[Argentina|Argentine]] business man and political figure, a close adviser to [[President of Argentina|President]] [[Juan Domingo Perón]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/Archivo/nota.asp?nota_id=883204 |title=Falleció el empresario peronista Jorge Antonio |date=13 February 2007 |newspaper=[[La Nación]] |language=es |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref>
==Life and times== Born '''Jorge Antonio Chibene''' in [[La Boca]], [[Buenos Aires]] to [[Syria]]n immigrants (his father was an émigré who arrived in Argentina from Syria in the 19th century, and whose name was Elias Antun Esquef), Antonio grew up in [[Uruguay]] and returned to Argentina at 17 years of age. He was an orderly at the [[Colegio Militar de la Nación|National Military Academy]] in 1942, and worked in several enterprises before being appointed as the representative of [[General Motors]] and [[Mercedes Benz]] in Argentina.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-80341-2007-02-13.html |title=Murió Jorge Antonio, un peronista de la primera hora |date=13 February 2007 |newspaper=[[Página/12]] |language=es |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> In this post, in 1949 he met Perón again, having first met him briefly in 1943, and would become one of Perón's most important advisers.<ref name="Revista Arabe">{{cite web |url=http://www.revistaarabe.com.ar/entrevistas_Jorge_Antonio.asp |title=Entrevista a Jorge Antonio |last=Pigna |first=Felipe |date=January 2004 |website=Revista Arabe |language=es |access-date=1 September 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115214109/http://www.revistaarabe.com.ar/entrevistas_Jorge_Antonio.asp |archive-date=15 January 2008}}</ref>
Antonio's fortune grew, connected with his friendship with Juan Duarte, Perón's brother-in-law. In the 1950s, Antonio bought the media companies [[Radio Belgrano]], [[TV Pública Digital (Argentina)|Canal 7]] and the [[Télam]] agency. He also invested in agribusiness and owned a bank, building his importance to the Presidency. It was reported that his fortune grew in the ten years to 1955 to US$ 215 million,<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,861748,00.html |title=Argentina: Wealth Recovery |date=19 December 1955 |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> and to opponents, Antonio's wealth became emblematic of the cronyism Perón encouraged during his Presidency.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,824193,00.html?iid=chix-sphere |title=Argentina: Dictatorship & Corruption |date=30 April 1956 |magazine=Time |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> Among his employees was [[Adolf Eichmann]], under his assumed name of Ricardo Clement.<ref name="Revista Arabe"/> Antonio admitted that he knew Eichmann's real identity.<ref name=clarin>{{cite news |url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/02/13/elpais/p-00701.htm |title=Murió Jorge Antonio, el hombre que conocía los mayores secretos de Perón |date=13 February 2007 |newspaper=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]] |language=es |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> He was often linked with stories of '[[Nazi Gold]]', money brought to Argentina, the [[United States]], and other safe havens by [[Nazis]] fleeing [[Germany]].
When Perón was deposed by the [[Revolución Libertadora|military coup]] of September 1955, Antonio refused to leave the country and was arrested. He was imprisoned for 17 days on a boat, then in [[Ushuaia]] for a month and later in [[Río Gallegos]] for two years. His properties were seized, and stolen with corrupted judges, by the military. In March 1957, with other Peronist leaders, he escaped from the prison and took refuge in [[Chile]]. He was able to fight off Argentine extradition appeals and eventually the government of [[Chile]] granted him asylum.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,809969,00.html |title=Chile: Let Jorge Do It |date=7 October 1957 |magazine=Time |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> In the following years, he lived in [[Cuba]] and then in [[Spain]], where he lived for 20 years. Despite animosity from Perón's wife, [[Isabel Perón|Isabel]], and the couple's chief of staff and fortune-teller, [[José López Rega]], Antonio was a prominent adviser and financier of the exiled populist leader.<ref>{{cite book |last=Page |first=Joseph A. |title=Perón: A Biography |location=New York |publisher=[[Random House]] |date=1983 |isbn=978-0-39452-297-5}}</ref>
However, in the 1970s Antonio was displaced by [[López Rega]], and when Perón returned to his country and was [[Argentine general election, September 1973|re-elected]] to the Presidency in 1973, Antonio opted to stay in [[Madrid]]. Except for a short stay in July 1974, on the occasion of the death of his mentor, Antonio did not return to Argentina until 1977.
He was also friend of [[Carlos Saúl Menem]], under whose presidency he once again became an influential man in the Argentinian business world. He had introduced Menem, also the son of Syrians, to Perón in 1964, though Antonio later distanced himself from the colorful Menem, who abandoned much of the populist Peronist platform during his presidency, in the 1990s.<ref name=clarin/>
Antonio died in 2007, a few months short of his 90th birthday. He had five children with his first wife Esmeralda, and three more were adopted in Spain.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/archivo/Nota.asp?nota_id=883483 |title=Con Jorge Antonio desapareció la última leyenda del peronismo |date=14 February 2007 |newspaper=La Nación |language=es |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Antonio, Jorge}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Argentine people of Syrian descent]] [[Category:Argentine people of Arab descent]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Adolf Eichmann]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} The '''Kennedy curse''' is a term for a series of deaths and calamities involving members of the [[Americans|American]] [[Kennedy family]].<ref name=WP>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/jfkjr/timeline.htm|title=Kennedy Family Tragedies|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=August 26, 2009|date=July 18, 1999}}</ref><ref name=tribune>{{cite news |first1= Pat |last1= Carr |first2= Lee |last2= Hulteng |url= http://www.courant.com/news/politics/20090826_tragedies_kennedy,0,5261652.graphic |title= Kennedy Family Tragedies |work= [[The Hartford Courant|The Courant]] |location= Hartford, CT |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=boston>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/packages/jfkjr/mcgrory.htm |title= Family Overshadowed by a Litany of Tragedy |work= [[The Boston Globe]] |last=McGrory |first= Brian|date=July 18, 1999|accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=boston/><ref name=klein>{{cite book |title= The Kennedy Curse: Why Tragedy Has Haunted America's First Family for 150 Years |last= Klein |first= Edward |authorlink= Edward Klein |year= 2004 |publisher= [[St. Martin's Press]] |isbn=978-0-312-31293-0}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/26/kennedy-curse-senator-ted-death |title=History of the Kennedy Curse |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= August 26, 2009 |last1= Jones |first1= Sam |last2= Tran |first2= Mark |accessdate= August 26, 2009 |location= London}}</ref><ref name=hartford>{{cite web|url=http://www.courant.com/news/politics/hc-kennedy-curse-pictures,0,1958578.photogallery|title=The Kennedy Curse|work= The Courant |location= Hartford, CT |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=abc>{{cite news |url= http://www.abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=1926999 |title= Is Pat's Crash Part of Kennedy Curse? |work= [[Good Morning America]] |publisher= [[ABC News]] |date= May 5, 2006 |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1918758,00.html?cnn=yes |title= Ted Kennedy, 1932–2009: The Brother Who Mattered Most |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |last= Lacayo |first= Richard |date= August 26, 2009 |accessdate= August 26, 2009}}</ref> [[Ted Kennedy]] publicly wondered whether a "curse actually did hang over all the Kennedys" during his own testimony about the [[Chappaquiddick incident]] in 1969.{{r|time19680801}} However, skeptics argue that many of the events are normal, and that it is not improbable for a large extended family to experience them.<ref name="skeptic">{{cite web |last= |first= |title= Kennedy Curse |work= [[The Skeptic's Dictionary]] |url= http://www.skepdic.com/kennedycurse.html |accessdate= August 29, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.irishcentral.com/story/news/periscope/talk-of-a-kennedy-curse-is-nonsense-latest-death-of-kara-revives-idle-chatter-130061473.html |title= Talk of a Kennedy Curse Is Nonsense, Latest Death of Kara Revives Idle Chatter |work= IrishCentral |last= O'Dowd |first= Niall |authorlink= Niall O'Dowd |date= September 18, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2012}}</ref>
==Chronology== Events that have been cited as evidence of the family's misfortunes include:
<!--Do **not** add Ted Kennedy (died at 77), Eunice Kennedy (88), or anyone else who died from a non-unusual reason (cancer is not unusual) or at a non-unusual age or without a source calling it part of the Kennedy Tragedy/Curse. Discuss at Talk.--> * 1941 — [[Rosemary Kennedy]] was often believed to have been [[Intellectual disability|intellectually disabled]], and due to her severe mood swings and the worry that she would damage the Kennedy reputation,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/the-exiled-kennedy-486688.html |title=The exiled Kennedy |last=El-Hai |first=Jack |date=January 15, 2005 |website=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print Limited |access-date=September 4, 2017 |quote=}}</ref> her father, [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.|Joseph Sr.]], arranged in secret for her to undergo a [[lobotomy]]. The lobotomy instead left her unable to walk or speak well, and as a result, Rosemary remained [[Psychiatric hospital|institutionalized]] until her death in 2005.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king">{{cite news |title= Tragedy Has Repeatedly Stalked Kennedy Clan |first= John |last= King |authorlink= John King (journalist) |publisher= CNN |date= July 17, 1999 |accessdate= February 15, 2008 |url= http://edition.cnn.com/US/9907/17/kennedy.tragedies/}}</ref><ref name="abc2012"/> Rosemary's condition may have inspired her sister, [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver|Eunice]], to initiate the [[Special Olympics]] in 1962. * August 12, 1944 — [[Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.]] died when his plane exploded over [[East Suffolk (county)|East Suffolk]], England, as part of [[Operation Aphrodite|Project Anvil]] during [[World War II]]. * May 13, 1948 — [[Kathleen Cavendish, Marchioness of Hartington]] died in a plane crash in [[France]].<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="abc2012"/> * August 9, 1963 — [[Patrick Bouvier Kennedy]] died of [[infant respiratory distress syndrome]] two days after his premature birth (which itself occurred on the 20th anniversary of his father's World War II rescue). Jackie missed the funeral because she was still recovering from the C-section at [[Otis Air National Guard Base|Otis Air Force Base]].<ref name=klein/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/for-john-and-jackie-kennedy-the-death-of-a-son-may-have-brought-them-closer/2013/10/24/2506051e-369b-11e3-ae46-e4248e75c8ea_story.html|title=For John and Jackie Kennedy, the death of a son may have brought them closer|last=Levingston|first=Steven|date=October 24, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=June 2, 2016}}</ref> * November 22, 1963 — [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[John F. Kennedy]] [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|was assassinated]] in [[Dallas|Dallas, Texas]] by [[Lee Harvey Oswald]]. Oswald was shot dead by [[Jack Ruby]] two days later before he could stand trial. In 1964, the [[Warren Commission]] concluded that Oswald was the lone assassin. In 1979, the [[United States House Select Committee on Assassinations]] (HSCA) concluded that the assassination was the result of a conspiracy and that Oswald did not act alone.<ref>{{cite web |first=Louis |last=Stokes|authorlink=Louis Stokes|title=Report of the Select Committee on Assassinations of the U.S. House of Representatives|year=1979|publisher=United States Government Printing Office |location=Washington, D.C. |url=https://www.archives.gov/research/jfk/select-committee-report/}} </ref> * June 19, 1964 — [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Kennedy]] was involved in a plane crash in which one of his aides and the pilot were killed. Ted was pulled from the wreckage by fellow senator [[Birch Bayh]] and spent weeks in a hospital recovering from a broken back, a punctured lung, broken ribs, and internal bleeding.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name="abc2012"/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/Kennedy-N344S.htm |publisher= Check-Six.com |title= The Luck of the Kennedys |accessdate= May 1, 2012 |date= May 8, 2008}}</ref> * June 5, 1968 — U.S. Senator [[Robert F. Kennedy]] [[Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy|was assassinated]] by [[Sirhan Sirhan]] in [[Los Angeles]] immediately following his victory in the California [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 1968|Democratic presidential primary]]. Sirhan pleaded guilty to Robert's murder and is serving a life sentence at the [[Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility]].<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="abc2012"/> * July 18, 1969 — In the [[Chappaquiddick incident]], Ted Kennedy accidentally drove his car off a bridge on [[Chappaquiddick Island]], which fatally trapped his 28-year-old passenger, [[Mary Jo Kopechne]], inside.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name=abc/><ref name="abc2012"/> Ted pleaded guilty to a charge of leaving the scene of the accident causing personal injury.<ref>Russell, Jenna (February 17, 2009). "Chapter 3: Chappaquiddick: Conflicted ambitions, then, Chappaquiddick". The Boston Globe. Archived from the original on February 21, 2010.Also published in the book The Last Lion: The Fall and Rise of Ted Kennedy, Simon & Schuster, 2009, chapter 3.</ref> In his televised statement a week later, Ted stated that on the night of the incident he wondered "whether some awful curse did actually hang over all the Kennedys."<ref name="time19680801">{{Cite magazine|date=August 1, 1969 |title=The Mysteries of Chappaquiddick |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,901159-1,00.html |magazine=Time |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831015242/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C901159-1%2C00.html |archive-date=August 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= 'Grief, Fear, Doubt, Panic' — And Guilt |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= August 4, 1969 <!--|accessdate=August 26, 2009-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite video |last= Kennedy |first= Ted |title= The Kennedys |medium= TV-series |work= [[American Experience]] |station= [[WGBH-TV]] |location= Boston |network= [[PBS]] |url= https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/kennedys/ |year= 2009 }}</ref> * August 13, 1973 — [[Joseph P. Kennedy II]] was the driver of a [[Jeep]] that crashed and left his passenger, Pam Kelley, paralyzed.<ref name=klein/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king" /> * April 25, 1984 — [[David A. Kennedy]] died of a [[cocaine]] and [[pethidine]] overdose in a [[Palm Beach, Florida]] hotel room.<ref name="klein" /><ref name="guardian" /><ref name="hartford" /><ref name="cnn-king" /><ref name="abc2012" /> * April 1, 1991 — [[William Kennedy Smith]] was arrested and charged with the rape of a young woman at the Kennedy estate in Palm Beach, Florida. The subsequent trial attracted extensive media coverage.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/archive/1992/03/dunne199203 |title= The Verdict |last= Dunne |first= Dominick |authorlink= Dominick Dunne |date= March 1992 |work= [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> Smith was acquitted.<ref name=WP/><ref name=boston/><ref name=klein/><ref name="cnn-king"/> * December 31, 1997 — [[Michael LeMoyne Kennedy]] died in a skiing accident in [[Aspen, Colorado]].<ref name=WP/><ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king" /><ref name="abc2012"/> * July 16, 1999 — [[John F. Kennedy Jr.]] [[John F. Kennedy Jr. plane crash|died]] when his plane he was piloting, a [[Piper PA-32R|Piper Saratoga]], crashed into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] off the coast of [[Martha's Vineyard]] due to [[pilot error]] and [[spatial disorientation]]. [[Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy|His wife]] and sister-in-law were also on board and died.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="abc2012"/> * September 16, 2011 — [[Kara Kennedy]] died of a heart attack while exercising in a [[Washington, D.C.]] health club at age 51. Kara had reportedly suffered from lung cancer nine years earlier, but she had recovered after the removal of part of her right lung.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8771095/Kara-Kennedy-dies-aged-51.html |title= Kara Kennedy Dies Aged 51 |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |last= Goddard |first= Jacqui |date= September 17, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 |location= London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2039733/Kara-Kennedy-Lung-cancer-cure-caused-heart-attack.html |title= 'I'm So Grateful I Have Those Memories': Joan Kennedy Remembers Last Summer with Daughter Kara Before She Died |work= [[The Daily Mail]] |date= September 21, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 |location= London}}</ref> * May 16, 2012 — [[Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.#Marriages and children|Mary Richardson Kennedy]] committed suicide on the grounds of her home in Bedford, [[Westchester County, New York]].<ref name="abc2012">{{cite web |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/kennedy-curse-political-familys-troubled-life/story?id=16362763 |title=Kennedy Curse: A Political Family's Troubled Life |publisher= ABC News |date= May 16, 2012 |last=Negrin |first= Matt |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jsfT2VoGbAR2P9uBoMOiCBb6817g?docId=788fa9391b1f42e993f59fe3312a837b |title= RFK Jr.'s Troubled Estranged Wife Found Dead in NY |work= Google News |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= May 16, 2012 |accessdate= May 16, 2012}}</ref> * September 4, 2018 — [[Christopher Kennedy Lawford]] died of a heart attack while doing hot yoga at a yoga studio in [[Vancouver, British Columbia]]. He was 63.
==Biographies== *''The Kennedy Curse: Why Tragedy Has Haunted America's First Family for 150 Years'' by Edward Klein, was published by St. Martin's Press.<Ref>[http://us.macmillan.com/books/9780312312930 The Kennedy Curse]</ref> *''The Kennedy Curse: Shattered'', a compilation of Kennedy curse accounts by Les Williams, was published in 9 November 2016 by Gayles Publishing.<Ref>[http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/books/803899/kennedy-curse-book-jfk-assassination-america-family-joe-mystery The Kennedy Curse busted: It was ALL Joe Kennedy’s fault and here's WHY]</ref><ref>[https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/kennedy-curse-shattered-les-williams The Kennedy Curse: Shattered]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Kennedy family}}
[[Category:Kennedy family]] [[Category:Curses]] [[Category:Assassination of John F. Kennedy]] [[Category:Urban legends]]

{{Infobox Magazine | name = Logistics Management | image = [[Image:Logistics management magazine cover.gif|Magazine cover of Logistics Management]] | caption = | type = [[business]] [[magazine]] | format = Paper and online magazine | foundation = 1962 | ceased publication = | price = | owners = Peerless Media | editor = | founder = | founded = 1962 | finaldate = | language = [[English language|English]] | publisher = EH Publishing, Inc. | political = | circulation = 70,074 | country = USA | based = [[Waltham, Massachusetts]] | ISSN = 1540-3890 | website = [http://www.logisticsmgmt.com Logistics Management] }}
'''''Logistics Management''''' ({{ISSN|1540-3890}}) is a trade publication and web site serving the information needs of the field of logistics and transportation.
==History and profile== Established in 1962, ''Logistics Management'' magazine is published monthly. Special reports, like the Logistics Outlook in January and the Buyers Guide in December, are provided on an annual basis.
Reed Business Information closed ''Logistics Management'' on April 16, 2010. On April 23, Reed sold its closed Supply Chain publications to a new company, Peerless Media, formed by Brian Ceraolo, former Group Publisher. The publisher and president of Peerless Media is [[Brian Ceraolo]]. The chief editor is [[Michael Levans]], with the editorial offices located in [[Framingham, Massachusetts]], USA.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jack W. Plunkett|title=Plunkett's Transportation, Supply Chain & Logistics Industry Almanac 2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdNVdg24S7sC&pg=PT121|accessdate=14 March 2016|date=1 March 2009|publisher=Plunkett Research, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-59392-142-2|page=121}}</ref>
As of December 2013, total [[BPA Worldwide|BPA]] audited circulation was 70,074 subscribers.
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.bpaww.com BPA Worldwide]
==External links== *[http://www.logisticsmgmt.com Logistics Management website] *[http://www.foliomag.com/2010/former-management-team-buys-back-4-rbi-titles Peerless Media LLC buys The Supply Chain Group]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Logistics Management (Magazine)}} [[Category:American monthly magazines]] [[Category:American business magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1962]] [[Category:Packaging magazines and journals]] [[Category:Professional and trade magazines]] [[Category:Waltham, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Magazines published in Massachusetts]]
{{trade-mag-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=February 2013}} [[File:Manuel Espinosa Batista.jpg|thumbnail|Bust of Manuel Espinosa Batista in Casco Viejo, Panamá]] '''Manuel Espinosa Batista''' (September 12, 1857 – November 27, 1919) was a [[Colombia]]n pharmacist turned politician who campaigned for a separate [[Panama]] state and became one of "Founders of the Republic". He is known for his philanthropy.
==Early life== Born in [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Manuel Espinosa Batista|url=http://micanaldepanama.com/nosotros/sobre-la-acp/historia-del-canal/proceres/manuel-espinosa-batista/|website=micanaldepanama.com|publisher=Canal de Panama|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref> Colombia, his father was Manuel Espinosa and his mother was Purificación Batista. At the early age of 13 he traveled to the [[Isthmus of Panama]] after being encouraged to do so by his relatives in [[Panama]]. He started to work for a pharmacy, raising money to pay for his books and pharmaceutical studies. Eventually, he became an expert pharmacist and established a [[pharmacy]] on Central Avenue in 1882, in front of the Arias-Feraud house (now known as Casa de la Municipalidad). A few months later, his great friend Jose Gabriel Duque was given a government contract to create a National Lottery and Manuel became his guarantor. Later, in 1899, Manuel became president of the company. Manual invested in, and created other business ventures.
==Political career== Manuel Espinosa Batista started his political life by winning a place in the city council from 1897 to 1898. He was a supporter of the separatist movement, which wanted the separation of Panama from Colombia. This group of separatists was formed by [[José Agustín Arango]], [[Manuel Amador Guerrero]], [[Nicanor de Obarrio]], [[Ricardo Arias]], [[Federico Boyd]], [[Carlos Constantino Arosemena]], [[Tomás Arias]], and Manuel Espinosa Batista. Nowadays they are called the "Founders of the Republic". [[José Agustín Arango]] organized meetings in the back part of the pharmacy owned by Manuel Espinosa Batista.
Panama achieved separation from Colombia on November 3, 1903. That night the local council proclaimed the separation and convened open [[Cabildo (council)|cabildo]] in [[Panama city]] the next day. During that cabildo, Panama independence was made official in an act signed by the members of the council and the citizens who attended the event. The President of the council [[Demetrio H. Brid]] appointed the Provisional Government Junta formed by: [[José Agustín Arango]], [[Tomás Arias]] and [[Federico Boyd]] - Manuel Espinosa Batista was appointed Deputy Member of the Provisional Government Junta, and his appointment was announce to each member by a note from [[Demetrio H. Brid]]. From November 9, 1903 to December 7, 1903 Manuel Espinosa Batista temporary replaced [[Federico Boyd]] within the Junta.
==Other Interests== Manuel Espinosa Batista not only acquired great economic, social, and political position during his life, but he was also a philanthropist. He granted scholarships to various boys with little resources, if they had willingness to study, and sent them overseas. In 1885 there was a great fire in [[Colón, Panama|Colón]] and many houses were destroyed, so he donated money to build new houses for the people who had lost everything. He also donated money to build streets in Panama city, donated money for the city's electric lighting, and for the recollection of garbage.
As a member of the city council, if there was not enough money to complete a scheme for the city, he would finance projects from his own pocket.
He also supported the orphanage administrated by the [[Salesians of Don Bosco]]. That orphanage later become the Don Bosco Technical Institute (Instituto Técnico Don Bosco), a private catholic school, which has a small building named Manuel Espinosa Batista.
==Family Life== He was married to Elisa Remón Escobar and they had seven children: María, Elisa, Isabel, Cecilia, Carmen, Raúl and Manuel Espinosa Remón. His wife, together with Hortensia de Alfaro, backed the closing show of the first art season in the Republic of Panama in 1910. This last show of the season was in benefit of the old people's home Bolívar and the children's orphanage.
==Legacy== Manuel Espinosa Batista died at the age of 62, on November 27, 1919. the day before the 63rd birthday of the President [[Belisario Porras]].
On December 16, 1924, the National Assembly of Panama, passed a law to commission a bronze bust sculpture of Manuel Espinosa Batista with the legend "Founder of the Republic", together with other busts of [[José Agustín Arango]], [[Tomás Arias]] and [[Federico Boyd]], members of the Provisional Government Junta and the bust of [[Manuel Amador Guerrero]], the first President of the Republic of Panama.
These busts are located in Independence Square, or Plaza Catedral, in Panama City. Later the busts of other members of the separatist movement were added to the square.
A public school and an avenue in Panama are named after Manuel Espinosa Batista.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Batista, Manuel Espinosa}} [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:Panamanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Panamanian politicians]]

revision.comment: This article is filled with general Baltimore history not specific to the hospital. This information should be created on its own page (ie, st Paul place) and linked to when mention in this article.

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Reynolds Securities | logo = [[File:Reynolds Securities logo.png|200px|Reynolds Securities logo from 1977]] | type = Merged | fate = Merged with [[Dean Witter & Co.]] in 1978 | predecessor = | foundation = 1931 | founder = [[Richard S. Reynolds, Jr.]] | location = [[New York City]], U.S. | industry = [[Financial Services]] | products = [[Brokerage]] | Subsidiaries = | revenue = | net_income = | assets = | homepage = | num_employees = }} '''Reynolds Securities''' was a publicly traded brokerage firm. Founded in 1931 by [[Richard S. Reynolds, Jr.]], the firm merged with [[Dean Witter Reynolds#Dean Witter & Co. (1924-1978)|Dean Witter & Co.]] to form [[Dean Witter Reynolds|Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc.]] in 1978, which was then the biggest merger in the history of [[Wall Street]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/10/04/archives/witter-reynolds-set-biggest-merger-in-wall-st-history-consolidation.html|title=WITTER, REYNOLDS SET BIGGEST MERGER IN WALL ST. HISTORY|last=Sloane|first=Leonard|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1977/10/04/dean-witter-reynolds-set-merger/2dce82ba-ed0f-4094-be2c-99821f24a91a/|title=Dean Witter, Reynolds Set Merger|last=Egan|first=Jack|date=1977-10-04|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
The firm's tagline, "We work for a world of investors. One at a time." was adapted to "We measure success one investor at a time" and was used by [[Dean Witter]] and later [[Morgan Stanley]].
==History==
Reynolds & Company was founded in 1931 in New York City by Richard S. Reynolds, Jr., a 22-year-old tobacco heir, together with Charles H. Babcock and Thomas F. Staley.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1980/10/06/richard-s-reynolds-jr-dies-at-72/0f0f3ac9-e572-4fc4-85c4-754da27b32d2/|title=Richard S. Reynolds Jr. Dies at 72|date=1980-10-06|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/11/Morgan-Stanley-Dean-Witter-Company.html|title=Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company - Company Profile, Information, Business Description, History, Background Information on Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company|website=www.referenceforbusiness.com|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/18419892/charles-henry-babcock|title=Charles Henry Babcock (1899-1967) - Find A Grave...|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref> In particular, Thomas F. Staley was Reynolds’ cousin (the grandson of Major D. Reynolds, an older brother of R.J. Reynolds). In 1951, another senior partner, John D. Baker, joined the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/07/25/obituaries/john-baker-dies-at-89-wall-street-executive.html|title=John Baker Dies at 89; Wall Street Executive|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en}}</ref>
Richard S. Reynolds' father [[Richard S. Reynolds, Sr.]] founded [[U.S. Foil Company]], later [[Reynolds Metals]] (Reynolds wrap), and his great uncle was the founder of [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]] (RJR).
Like [[Dean Witter Reynolds#Dean Witter & Co. (1924-1978)|Dean Witter & Co.]], the company survived the Depression, generating a profit each year. In 1934, Reynolds acquired F.A. Willard & Co.<ref>Owen, David. [https://books.google.com/books?id=iEwE89P6hr8C&pg=RA1-PA74 The Making of the Masters]. 1999</ref> With the acquisition, Reynolds tripled its sales and shifted its emphasis toward underwritings.<ref name="DWHistory">[https://web.archive.org/web/19970419005212/http://www.deanwitter.com/about/history.html Dean Witter History] (Archived). Retrieved, June 9, 2010</ref>
In 1958, Reynolds passed its leadership to the next generation with Thomas F. Staley departing and naming Robert M. Gardiner to head the firm. Under Gardiner, Reynolds embarks on major expansion, acquiring 26 offices from A.M. Kidder & Co. Reynolds acquired another three offices and opened nine firms in new regions in the U.S. in the early 1960s.<ref name=DWHistory />
Reynolds was incorporated in 1971 as Reynolds Securities in advance of an initial public offering. By early 1971, there was speculation that Merrill Lynch would sell shares to the public. Reynolds initial public offering (and shortly thereafter Dean Witter's IPO) was part of a rush of Wall Street firms to sell an interest in their privately held businesses to public investors, following Merrill Lynch's initial public offering.<ref name=newmoney>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,902916,00.html New Money for Merrill Lynch]. Time Magazine, Apr. 26, 1971</ref> In 1976, Reynolds implements REYCOM, the most sophisticated high-speed wire system in the industry. Meanwhile, the firm was continuing its expansion, acquiring its first international offices in [[Lugano]] and [[Lausanne, Switzerland]].<ref name=DWHistory /> A year later, Reynolds acquired Baker Weeks & Co. whose strength was securities research.<ref>Matthews, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0R0WudQp0bcC&pg=PA107 Struggle and survival on Wall Street]. 1994</ref>
At the time of its merger with Dean Witter & Co. in 1978, Reynolds Securities had over 3,100 employees in 72 offices producing gross revenues of nearly $120 million.<ref name=DWHistory />
==See also== *[[Dean Witter Reynolds]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Financial services companies based in New York City]] [[Category:Financial services companies established in 1931]] [[Category:Reynolds family]] [[Category:1931 establishments in New York (state)]]
